qas.question: What two sources of energy use do DST proponents say are reduced by the time change?
What word describes the approximate rates at which sunset and sunrise change with the seasons?
Do those who favor DST say people would rather have an extra hour of daylight before or after their usual workday?
Is it the supporters or opponents of Daylight Saving Time who say it significantly reduces energy use?

context: While the times of sunrise and sunset change at roughly <a1_0>equal<a1_0/> rates as the seasons change, proponents of Daylight Saving Time argue that most people prefer a greater increase in daylight hours <a2_0>after<a2_0/> the typical "nine-to-five" workday. <a3_0>Supporters<a3_0/> have also argued that DST decreases energy consumption by reducing the need for <a0_0>lighting and heating<a0_0/>, but the actual effect on overall energy use is heavily disputed.
